text: 750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 1/26/2017. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy very dark brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of huge caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, brown sugar, vanilla, maple, molasses, bourbon, toasted oak, coconut, brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of raisin, plum, fig, cherry, date, and roast/toast/oak earthiness. Lightly increasing booze in the aromas as it warms, but never overwhelming. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt, bourbon barrels, and light-moderate fruity yeast notes; with great strength. Taste of huge caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, brown sugar, vanilla, maple, molasses, bourbon, toasted oak, coconut, brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of raisin, plum, fig, cherry, date, and roast/toast/oak earthiness. Light roast bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, brown sugar, vanilla, maple, molasses, bourbon, toasted oak, coconut, brown bread, nuttiness, dark fruit, cherry, and roast/toast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, bourbon barrels, and light-moderate fruity yeast flavors; with an awesome roasted bitter/sweet and bourbon/oak spiciness balance; and with zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Slight dryness from roast bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness, lightly increasing through the glass. Light-medium carbonation and fairly full body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky, and slightly slick/sticky/chalky/tannic balanced mouthfeel that is awesome. Mildly warming alcohol from 16.3%, with minimal barrel booziness. Overall this is an amazing barrel aged blended strong ale! All around incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, bourbon barrels, and light-moderate fruity yeast flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on for the huge ABV. More of an old ale on style, but still has nice levels of chocolaty roast presence. Perfect balance of barrels; adding plenty of complexity to the base blend, without being boozy or overly tannic. An insanely enjoyable offering.

This draft brew from a beer bar was served at a cool temperature and poured a extremely small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were fully diminished and left behind no visible carbonation opaque dark brown colored body and a fair lacing. The nice aroma was molasses brown malt dark malt and bourbon. The vinous mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a mellow bourbon aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of molasses brown sugar sassafras bourbon brown malt and dark malt. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.

Bottle, shared @ Potjepalooza.
pours brown/red with a light very limited head. aroma of bourbon, rye, roasted and toasted malts, caramel and a lot of dark fruits.
taste of heavy sweetnes, alcoholic, roasted and toasted, chocolate, raisins, full, caramel, heavy lots of alcohol, a bit too alcoholic
full body, soft carbo.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2017 Bottle, shared @ Potjepalooza. 2012 edition (15%), from an IP trade with richiesd. Dark brown color with a red hue. Head is immediately receding. Aromas of dried fruit, a bit dusty, sweet, fruity, alcohol. Retronasal its alcoholic, sweet, fruity, sourish. Flavor is sweet, sweet fruit, alcoholic. Pretty strong alcohol feel, burning. Full bodied. Long finish, alcoholic, caramellish, fruity.

Shared from bottle at Potjepalooza. Dark brown with cream head. Big sweet roasted caramel malts. Big ass barleywine. Marzipan, heavy alcohol. Big sweet and medium bitter. Full body and soft carbonation.

Bottle shared at Potjepalooza. Clear mahogany with small off white head. Lots of bourbon, alcohol, marzipan, candy, lots of cola, light chocolate, quite some peach, candies lemon, chocolate, dates and raisins. Very sweet with lots of alcoholic bitterness. Almost feel bodied. Nice stuff but too alcoholic.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2017 Bottle, 2014 edition. Pours dark ruby, with small beige head. Beautiful aromas of dark dried fruits like dates, figs, raisins, lots of toffee and some milk chocolate notes. Taste is mostly sweet, with lots of fruitiness, nice alcohol warming. A masterpiece, especially if you are into barley wine type beers.
On tap at Victoria Gastropub. Translucent medium brown. Aroma is caramel, thick body, low carbonation, and pretty good small-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel and big malt.  Hard to drink.

Aromas of aged malts, barrel wood, bourbon, leatther, oak, wort malt, molasses, toffee, vanilla, wafers, sugared caramel, port wine, merlot, charred malts, plums, coconut flakes and alcohol sugars. Pours a very dark crimson brown with a quarter white foam and no lacing. Taste brings complex dark malts, toffee, sugared dark fruits, prunes, raisins, molasses, wort malt, oak and brown sugar. Mid palate offers insane barrel qualities like, oak, bourbon, vanilla, barrel wood, leather, cigar smoke, sugared caramel and slight coconut spruce. Finishes boozy with tons of bourbon and aged malts. Some barley wine qualities are noticeable with tons of dark fruits. Overall, an absolute masterpiece production of a blended beer. The best qualities of each individual beer. A+ rating.
Bottle - Boozy and toffee with cocoa. Cloudy brown with a small beige head. Prune and date with some sweetness. Big, rich and lots of brown fruits.
Draft. Pours dark amber. Thick head. The taste is sweet and caramel. The bourbon sticks out a lot. Awesome beer

(The Bruery Melange #3) Bottle 750 ml at home, served into a snifter, ABV 15.5%
Dark brown coloured beer, hazy body, small and a bit thin dark beige head on top, average retention.
Aroma of vanilla, alcohol, light caramel, toffee, wood, dark fruits.
Taste is sweet with lots of dark fruits, bourbon, vanilla, plenty of alcohol, figs, caramel, light toffee, hints of chocolate, even more alcohol on the finish.
Thick body with good carbonation.
Good heavy beer.
Sample from bottle at Bruery, Placentia. Colour is deep dark brown with very small head. Aromas and flavors: Chocolate, wood, some dryness, oak, vanilla and malts. Excellent.

Thanks Mr Miller for sharing the bottle! Poured into a taster showing moderately filtered porter brown with no head. 

The nose shows light caramel. 

The palate is light bodied and highly carbonated. Moderately sweet with light flavors of vanilla and caramel with a light smoky finish.

Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Perfekcyjny Barleywine z czekoladowym finiszem. Doskonale ukryty alkohol, kapitalnie rozgrzewa w żołądku. Przepiękne piwo.
Bottle @ Borefts 2016 thanks Stu666. Pours brown red, off white head. Nose is caramel, coffee, slight vanilla. Taste is woody, vanilla, slight oak, some whisky, maple syrup.
Bardzo dobre, złożone, marcepanowe, dużo bourbonu, wanilii, słodyczy. Potężne ciało i miła faktura. Bardzo dobra rzecz.
Bottle at the xmas tasting. Pours deep ruby, nose is vanilla, caramel, toffee, taste is rich, sweet, bourbon, caramel, citrus, juicy.
750ml bottle. Dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma of toffee, butterscotch and oak. Sweet taste with tonnes of dark fruits, vanilla, cola and molasses. Lovely complexity to it. Great stuff.
Bottle at the 2nd Annual Garvie Christmas Tasting. Pours hazy brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of booze, nutty, almonds, hot. Taste is almonds, boozy bourbon, faint chocolate. Boozy finish.

bottle at home ... dark brown ... thin tan lacing ... soft boozy .. deep fruit .. soft cherry .. big bourbon nnsoe ... dark sweet fruits .. dark roast .. massive chcolate malts .. big fruits  ... black cherries but dirty woody oaky bourbon
Very pricey draught pour at Pazzos. Big and boozy and sticky with caramel and toffee. But so big. Just not my thing still.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2016 Tap Pizza Luce Richfield. Very dark red-brown pour with a small head. Molasses, bourbon and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is sweet, bourbon, chocolate, molasses. Excellent!

Un grand merci à Yan pour le partage! Je suis assumé: jaime Bruery et ses grosses bières cochonnes et décadentes. Bruery cest Bruery: idolâtrée par les buveurs de craft beer débutants, souvent méprisée par les connaisseurs qui ny voient que du tappe à loeil sucré et grossier. Moi jaime Bruery. À loccasion me prend une rage dune de leurs énormes monstres barriqués et lorsque. Jai alors besoin de mon fix. Teinte de Cognac âgé, texture huileuse, collante au verre, sans mousse. Le liquide est ambré et ressemble à un alcool que le temps a fortifié. Un nez sur la vanille caramélisée, le bourbon, le bois, le caramel. Cest cochon! Jaime ça! Des notes de toasts de pain de grains germés. Peut-être un sirop de maïs également. Étonnamment beaucoup de sucre en bouche (?), mêlé à une bonne dose dépices, de caramel et dalcool. Bière aux allures robuste mais au coeur dor et fragile. La lumber-sexual de la bière!

Shared bottle at RB Crete tasting at Nikos place, Chania. Pours very dark ruby with a small tan head. Aroma of raisins, vinous complexity in the nose. Moderate sweet malty taste, loaded with raisins vanilla and wood, strong and powerful, well hidden alcohol.

From notes. Enjoyed this baby at a line share at Witchs Hat on St. Pattys Day. 750 mL bottle poured by an increasingly drunken Uncle Rudi. Man this guy is annoying. This was a 2012 vintage. The beer is great, his company, not so much. The pour is a dark brown with some ruby or dark red hues shining through. There is a small tan head roiling down with a little lace. The aroma is pretty fantastic. There is a ton of sweetness right up front, big sugar, molasses, caramel, and a surprising note of vanilla. There is a good chocolate malt and a nice dark fruit in there as well. There is a touch of heat, which is to be expected, but it balances very well. The flavor is much of the same. There is a little bit of sweet candy in here behind the sugar and molasses. The chocolate, vanilla, and caramel really play well together in a makeshift sundae in my mouth. The mouth feel is thick and creamy with a soft carbonation and a lingeringly sweet sugary finish. This one is excellent. The guy pouring might suck, but his beer is pretty okay.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour murky brown with small ecru head. Nose light sour, molasses caramel, dates. Taste big sweet up front, syrupy sweet, candied fruit, raisin. Late palate heat from alcohol, almost rubbing alcohol. Thick mouth feel.

Bottle shared with koleminer20, Gus, and others. 2012 vintage. Aroma is barrel, dried fruit, roasted malt, sweet, wonderful. Appearance is brown, light brown head, nice. Taste is candy, barrel, sweet, fuck, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, just a party in my mouth. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy, light carbonation, sweet candy aftertaste. Overall, yowza. This is fucking unbelievable.

On tap at the Bruery tasting room. It pours a dark amber brown color with a light tan head. The aroma is very nutty and woody with lots of chocolate, raisin, almonds, fig and alcohol. The flavor is strong and alcoholic with sweet notes of fig, raisin, cocoa and caramel. Lots of wood and vanilla as well. Alcohol is pretty noticeable. Has an aged quality about it. A really nice fireside sipper.

A 750 ml-es üvegek királya, a The Bruery főzde palackjainak mindegyike magán hordoz egyfajta elit-jelleget, az embernek ugyanis rendre olyan érzése támad az elegáns küllemű darabok láttán, hogy a bennük rejlő ital igazi különlegesség hordozója, olyan, melyre érdemes odafigyelni. Nem mondhatnám, hogy a márka főzeteinek legnagyobb ismerője vagyok, az eddigi tapasztalatok azonban megerősíteni látszanak az exkluzív jelleget a Bruery-sörök tekintetében, különösen ha egy díjnyertes elegy hordozója a főszereplő, mely nem akármilyen komponensekből állt elő, s amely alkoholfok tekintetében sem utolsó. Ez az american strong ale nem viccel, amikor intenzív jellegről, kiemelkedő tartalomról, makulátlan szerkezetről esik szó, egyszerűen lenyűgöző karakter tárul elénk a felnyitását követően. Illata marcipános, karamelles és vaníliás, sokszínűsége magával ragadó. A műfaj valamennyi sajátosságát megcsillantja, magán visel minden jegyet, amely egy hasonló kaliberű főzettől elvárható. Az american strong ale afféle iskolapéldája, amely anélkül vonultatja fel gigantikus arzenálját, hogy azok súlya alatt előbb-utóbb repedezni kezdenének az alapok, s fogyasztója számára megterhelővé válna a karakter. Itt ugyanis bár semmi esetre sem hétköznapi italról van szó, nem válik nyomasztóvá a különleges jelleg, a sokadik korty után sem állít kihívás elé a tartalom befogadása. A mondanivaló ugyanis tökéletesen lekerekített és fogyasztóbarát, az igényességre törekvés menthetetlenül kiütközik a szerkezeten. Bár a vanília, a fahordós-tölgyes jelleg, a karamella, a marcipános és likőrös jegyek, a fekete gyümölcsök hangulata nem a visszafogottság megtestesítői egy sör esetében, s ezen intenzív komponensek jelenléte a kezdeti lehengerlő hatást követően hamar átcsaphat csömörbe, a kiegyensúlyozottság foka, a tökéletesen alátámasztott test ez esetben gondoskodik a minőség folyamatos biztosításáról, az érdeklődés lankadatlanságáról, az izgalmak szüntelenségéről. S ahogyan az intenzív jelleg a kortyolása során mindvégig megmarad, olyannyira lapul meg a háttérben az alkoholfok cseppet sem elhanyagolható, mégis észrevétlenül munkálkodó mértéke.

On tap at The Bruery. Hazy brown appearance. Aroma of oak, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, toffee and hints of dark fruits and bourbon spice. Full body. The alcohol is hidden fairly well considering the ABV. Nicely done overall.

June 13, 2015. Bottle, received in a trade with atlcarl, thanks! 
Murky reddish brown with a very small frothy off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty and light boozy with caramel, dried fruits, dark bread, orange notes, wood and warming bourbon alcohol. Taste is quite sweet, malty and boozy with caramel, figs, raisins, some roasted malt and wood notes, prunes, vanilla and a warming finish. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation.

The beer is dark brown with a promise of deep amber richness. Small beige head, which dies away to nothing quickly and leaves no lacing behind. The aroma is all big, rich toasted and roasted malt sugars under the influence of seductively sweet spirit barrels. Its all rich caramel, treacle, toffee and juicy juicy vanilla. Theres also some deep malt fruitiness to it. Overripe apricots, musty grapes, raisins, figs, dates - sweet, sugary stuff. Big on the figs and dates, particularly. The taste is uncompromisingly sweet and rich. Lush, toasty sugars. Wonderfully full caramel malt flavors. Big, round mouthfeel. Enjoyable. Its sweet without being overbearing. Very easy to like.

Very cloudy, light mahogany, light white head. Deep fig, chocolates, toffee. Some spice. Pleasantly bitter, very intensely sweet. Very long oily finish, but not nearly as alcoholic as would be expected at 17%. Excellent.

Bottle. Pours brown with small head. Aroma mainly dried fruits, caramel, alcohol and some oaky vanilla notes. In taste medium sweet with caramel, fruits and vanilla and counteted by booze and medium bitterness. Full bodied, softly carbonated, oily and a bit arsh from alcohol.

750ml bottle - pours a murky amber . Aroma is notes of cocoa and dried fruit . Lots going on in this beer . Alcohol was very well hidden . Excellent . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark reddish brown with a thin film of foam and some bubbles at the edges of the glass. Huge nose with notes of caramel, boozy dark fruits, milk chocolate and bourbon. The taste christmas fruits, big malty backbone, vinous fruit, boozy and spicy chokolate cake - typical Brewery big! All kinds of spice and fruitcake in the aftertaste with a slight boozy burn. Obnoxious beer.

Omg. Thanks hoprider. What are you doing to me? 
Pour slightly murky dark mahogany brown, with a very small tan head. 
Aroma is so freekin packed with all kinds of goodness. Black tuesday is definately here, chocolate, dark fruits soaked in bourbon, vanilla, bourbon, wet wood, slight tanins, coconut. Im speechless, I didnt know what to expect, but man, this is better than that. 
Taste is pretty sweet, but sure has some bitter notes to it. Definately some alcohol burn to it, but not quite 17%. 
Body is fucking oily and flat. Fuck it losers, Im done with this rating. Its much. I quit. Fuck me.

Murky brown. Boozy vanilla and brown sugar. Caramel. Blended stout. Sticky. Lots of SUPER boozy caramel. Alcohol counters the sweetness really well. Ends quite boozy, but on this rare occasion, I actually appreciate that about this beer. This is what Firestone wants their anny brews to be. Deeeelicious.

This beer was truly amazing. It poured pitch black with aromas of coconut, caramel, toffee, rich dark malt, and chocolate. The taste was more of the same, with a nice sweet finish. The alcohol is completely hidden, so if you get a bottle be careful as I could have finished the whole thing by myself, but I would have probably been passed out and would not remember.
Wow, popped a 2 year old version and it was just an explosion of booze, sweetness, chocolate, dark fruit and it was a full experience drinking this one. A definite share beer, unless you're crazy.
Very good beer. Bourbon character overwhelms. Smooth. Well Balanced. Flavor complexity actually exceeds aroma. Awesome beer.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; clear dark chestnut brown pour with a thin beige head, aroma has bourbon, hint of vanilla, dark fruits, big booze, taste has big dark fruits, coconut, bourbon, a hint of vanilla, wood, raisins, very bold beer.

De Grote Black Tuesday Tasting: 13 Versions. For all versions: 750 ml. bottles sampled. 2011 Black Tasting (4.1/5) vs. 2013 Black Tuesday (4.3/5). Neither were gushers unlike the 2012 I tried once before. Both pour very dark brown with some black, virtually no head in both cases. Some lone bubbles with the 2011, nothing at all with the 2013. Alcohol is huge in both cases, a touch lower in the 2011, some light oxidation & varnish notes in the 2011, thick bourbon, mocha, Alcohol is even bigger in the nose with the 2013, harsh & brutal. Raw white spirit almost. More mocha, sweeter chocolates & very thick mocha in the nose in the 2013. 2011 carries some light oxidation in the taste, less raw, big burning alcohol in the finish but overall a bit muted, some weird notes here, leaves, varnish, touch oxidation, making this one the lesser one of the two. You also get hugely thick molasses, harsh bourbon, Body is low carbonation & molasses, pure syrup. Booze is huge, in the 2013, vodka, raw spirit, burns, the taste is niches, thick syrup, more cacao, chocolate, sweet cacao nibs, not getting oxidation here, molasses, chocolate syrup. Same thick molasses. Overall a fun beer due to its extremity but it is also bit of a caricature, too excessive. Overall I am not crazy about it but I do like but it far from all that impressive. Winefication I (4.2/5) + Winefication II (4.4/5) (obtained in a trade with AdamChandler. Thx!) side-by-side. Winefication I pours a very deep red Bordeaux, little bubbles. Nose is quite strange, the two components seem to clash a bit here, molasses, mocha, sweet, umami, big roasted oak, soy sauce with thick dry sweet red wine, odd. Taste is huge oak, massive roast, wine character dominates, this one is a bit hard to describe for me, raisins, huge dry strong boozy red wine with huge church incense taste, dry, red grape skins, touch plastic, fruit punch, Thick & dry. Very much a strong basic red wine with some components that clash a bit, interesting to say the least. Winefication II is hugely different, also massively wine-like but just a different wine. This one is a better wine, less conflict here just a supper thick wine. Pours a very dark red Bordeaux, little bubbles. Nose is light mocha but largely hugely vinous, lots of oak, dry red grapes. Taste is huge oak, lots of roast (very much as was the case with the I), lots of roasted barrel, interesting mix of licorices, wine leaves, wine ranks, red grape, huge dry red frape spins, light plastic, vinous, warming (strangely tasted about as strong as I despite the huge ABV difference),.. Very thick, weird, unique & interesting. Melange #1 (4.5/5).Very dark brown, solid mocha head. Nose is huge red wine, balsamic vinegar, very tart, puckering red fruit, Not getting any Black Tuesday here. Taste is puckering sour red grapes, wine, faint glue, balsamic vinegar, pomegranate, sour cherries, Very thick body & puckering. Lovely. Not getting any Black Tuesday here oddly & like it more than Oude Tart. Quite simple but also very nice. This should be the 3rd batch made. Melange #3 (3.8/5): Very dark brown with a deep red hue and no head. Nose is weird, almost a bit like Black Tuesday (dominates heavily) with something sourish (White Sap I suppose), glue, bourbon, heavy alcohol, glue, oak, lots of bourbon. Taste is weird, faintly sour vanilla, thick bourbon, boozy Black Tuesday, molasses, thick basic licorice, syrup, Thick, boozy. Strange mix. Doesnt fully work for me. Least favorite of the 13. Chocolate Rain 2013 (4.7/5): Very dark brown to black, only some bubbles as is usual. Nose is huge thick sweet mocha, milk chocolate, vanilla, sweet bourbon, thick candy, molasses, thick & sweet. Taste is huge vanilla, bourbon, warming, mocha, vanilla, cacao, sweet chocolate, molasses, thick, sweet. Awesome, this is the 3rd time I have this beer, still surprised by how well it really works. So much better than the base beer. Grey Monday (4.2/5): Black / brown, zero head as usual. Hugely alcoholic nose, syrup, mocha, molasses. Taste is hugely boozy, molasses, thick syrup, very straightforward & basic, mocha, exotic sugar. Very basic, body is alcohol & molasses. Second time I have this beer & I am still not getting the hazelnuts. This one is still a bit pointless for me. 2013 Mocha Wednesday (4.4/5): Black, dark brown with no head. Nose is weird charcoal, ashes, burned wood & hugely roasted espresso beans. Taste & smell carries so much more roast & coffee than I remember this one having. Taste is burned mocha, charred barrels, huge roasted espresso, molasses, charcoal, mocha, sugar & molasses sweetness in the back. Basic but nice, quite an interesting heavily roasted espresso tastes & charred barrels. Thick body as usual. Rum (4/5), Madeira (4.4/5) & Port BA (4.4/5) versions next to each other. First two look as expected, very dark brown, dash black with basically no head. Port one has very dark red hue. Rum is the least one, even less than the base beer. Kind of pointless since the rum is far too muted & doesnt seem to add much, the base beer sort of drowns it out. Nose is sweet booze, mocha, very basic, pretty much Black Tuesday without bourbon, more sugar. Taste is boozy overly syrupy, barrel, big oak, very alcoholic, basic brown sugar, candy, mocha, roast, brown sugar. Okay but less than regular Black Tuesday & clearly lesser than Madeira or Port. Madeira: nose is hugely sweet mocha, sweet sugar, light complimentary barrel, sweet light red wine, faint red fruits. Taste is hugely sweet, spirit, coated in oak, old strong wine, huge brown sugar, vinous alcohol, sugar, oak, molasses. Thick chewy. Works rather well. Better than regular Black Tuesday & prob. my fav. of these 3 (Rum, Madeira & Port). Hard to choose between this one & port. Port: nose is huge red wine, massively so with strong alcohol, candy & lots of barrel. Taste is huge port, red wine, booze, light molasses, plenty of barrel, roast, oak, light chocolate, thick. Quite interesting & nice, also better than the regular one for me. Final one: Black Tuesday Reserve (4.6/5). Usual appearance. Nose is huge bourbon, warming, toffee, molasses, bourbon, boozy but oddly less so than the regular one, this is one is much rounder, chocolate, caramel, fruity even. Taste is vanilla, huge mocha, chocolate, overripe fruit, molasses, cereal, sugar, warming, syrupy, finish is heavily booze but the booze is in the back here as opposed to everywhere in the regular, barrel, oak, cacao, mocha. So much rounder, richer. Way better than expected, nice surprise, very big beer.
Pours dark brown with a small light ta head. Quite complex aroma; bourbon vanilla and dades..flavours; complex with some carbonation with bourbon, brunt sugar, vanilla and alcohol..
A: dark brown, no head N: Bourbon, vanilla, dadels, apricot, oak T: Bourbon, vanilla, orange O: Very complex and quite boozy.

Another damn perfect beer from placentia. Pours very dark with bourbon and complex malty character. No real head but enough carbonation to satisfy great mouthfeel with its touch richness. Finishes like blended malt scotch with toffee and light espresso.

Pours dark with no head
Aromas of bourbon barrel, vanilla, figs, dades, alcohol
Taste has nice tones of vanilla, muscavado, bourbon, alcohol, burned caramel, butterscotch

Pours very dark brown, almost black with a low tan head. Aromas of muscovado sugar, chocolate, burnt sugar. Taste is muscovado sugar, burnt sugar, slight liqourice, vanilla, slight booze. Mouthfeel is very smooth and velvety with almost no carbonation.
Bottle in line for Blåbær 15. Dirty dark amber pour with some lacings. Tons of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, sweet malts, leather and toffee.

Pours an amber brown color with very little head. Oak, bourbon, dark fruit, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, toffee and spice flavors and aroma. Full body and moderate carbonation. Oak, vanilla and bourbon finish.

Bottle shared at Blåbær Lambic release. Pours hazy dark reddish brown. Aromas of booze, caramel, malts, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, chocolate. Taste is booze, caramel, malt, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, toffee, woody notes, light sweet licorice.

750 mL bottle poured and shared by Tcon. Huge thanks for sharing this one, with a nice touch of about a year of age on the bottle. I can only imagine it made this incredible beer even more enjoyable. Pours a dark muddy brown color with a thin ring head. What a fun blend this is. Heavy raisin, toffee, oak, and spice aroma. Flavor has some vanilla, wood, toffee, and chocolate. So much going on here. Very complex, which is no surprise, considering its a blend of three beers that are plenty complex on there own. Has a bit of a lingering bourbon finish. Slightly cool, and boozy, though not off putting. I cant say that I absolutely love the flavor entirely, I am easily able to admire it. Overall, this was a fun beer to finally try. Very much a big league beer, and is an ass kicker, but enjoyable to say the least.
Bottle pour split at the condo. Got this for Andrew and I to split for him getting married. Dark deep amber, sweet aroma kindof boozy, rich flavor raise, some coco, really awesome beer to try.
Bottle @ ZEBF 2015. Dark oily pour. Delicious aroma of vanilla, cherry and chocolate. Taste of soft vanilla, milky chocolate, cherry, coffee, oak and with an everlasting finish. Extremely good.
Liquorish and very well balanced blend. Chocolate and a lot of bourbon. Somewhat sweet finish.
A very nice blend of different brews. The brewery haves even better beers, but this one is no shame nether for sure.
2012 vintage in 750ml bottle. Pours a brown color with a surprising amount of carbonation for the strength. Aroma of plums. Flavor of plum and a touch of pepper. So smooth.

2011 bottle from a trade a long time ago over my birthday weekend May, 2015. Dark reddish brown. Nose of sweet vanilla, bourbon, light baking spices. Rich toffee, some dark dried fruit, light milk chocolate, and a lot of cinnamon and barrel spice as it warmed. Had it with smores and it held up quite well, even got spicier. Really good, but a sweet and hot and probably on its way out.

Shared 2014 bottle by a friend. Poured a cola to more chesnut Brown colour with a small non lasting off ring. Leading into Some alcohol legs on the Side. Nose is instantly hit with sweet bourbon, sweet notice of toffee, caramel, bourbon covered raisins, nutmeg, alcohol spice, small notice of chocolate, oak, and more sticky bourbon in the end. More red fruits as its starting to warm. Pretty sweet finish. Wich i kind of like. To bad there is not as much black tuesday notice as i was expecting

Bottle: Dark mahogany, oily pour with almost no head. Very, very fine khaki-colored trace. Aroma is huge, a ménage a trois of barrel-aging, stout, & barley wine. Burnt caramel, figs, vanilla, boozy bourbon, spicy oak, toffee, molasses, butterscotch, prunes, faint maple syrup, underlying roast, a hint of dark cocoa powder, a touch of anise, faint leather, black cherry. Very big & complex. Flavor is the same. Its not "HOT" but its very, very warming. Bourbon forward with lots of oaky tannins, spicy wood, vanillin, & hints of sherry. Cocoa dust, toffee, roasted malts, caramel, raisins, figs covered in brown sugar & dipped in cognac. A dessert beer, & a slow sipper no doubt. But a very good one.
Smells like a sweet, hot mess, but the palate is magic. Complex, developing sweetness that range from vanilla and chocolate to dried fruit, toffee cake and candy. Fabulous desert.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2015 750 ml waxed bottle (2013 Edition bottled 10/28/2013) poured into a snifter. Dark brownish with a finger of beige to light tan head. Aromas of rich caramel, toffee, dark fruit, slight bourbon. Tastes of brown sugar, rich milk chocolate, dark fruit, caramel, a little oak and bourbon thats possibly faded from age. Very sweet and rich with some booze. Medium body with a dry and warm finish. Medium-low carbonation. Nice blend.

Bottle. Vintage 2013. Apperance is light brown with white head. Aroma is a mix of choclate, cherries, oak, bourbon, and vanilla. Taste is rich vanilla up front, followed by oak mixed in with some light vinious undertones. Finshes with a bit of light tartness and vanilla, lingering heat from the ABV. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, medium carbonatioin. This is a really nice blend, I actually didnt find it too sweet but its certainly would be tough to take down a whole bottle on your own.
2014 750ml bottle pours a hazy brown with an off white head. toffee bourbon vanilla and dried fruit taste. very good mix of beer here

Bottle. 2011 from Shane. Thanks!

A: Opaque mahogany, thin cappuccino head, legs.

N: Bourbon, sherry, caramel, port, cocoa, vanilla, maybe some rum, brown sugar, more sugars, 

T: Super sweet, yet not cloying. Only sweet.

M: Heavy body, oily and slick, fuzzy carbonation. There is most definitely alcohol. 

O: Gigantic sweetie. Big caramel and easy enough to drink. Not much to compare it to.

Bottle to glass. Pours a cloudy deep nut brown color with a thin light tan head. Aroma is boozy, bourbon, toffee, vanilla. Flavor is hot, bourbon, light toffee and toasted malts. Huge beer with a strong boozy burn in the finish. Tasty, but these beers always have a massive feel. Hard to finish a bottle without splitting it with a fee friends.

2012 vintage poured from a 750 ml bottle. 
Aroma is loaded with caramel, toffee and burnt sugar with hints of chocolate and roast. Moderate notes of dried figs, prunes and dates with raisin as well. Medium light oak character with faint vanilla and some spice. 
Pours a murky, burnt amber with a small, fairly thick, dark tan head that recedes to a thin film that lingers in the center and on the edges. Medium light lacing and moderate legs. 
Flavor is fairly sweet with a stupidly large amount of dark caramel and toffee with lighter notes of toasted bread and burnt sugar. Medium light chocolate character and faint roast. Lots of dark fruit, again most of it being figs, prunes, dates and raisins. Medium light oak note and light vanilla with some peppery spice notes. Medium light alcohol in the finish with lingering sweetness, burnt sugar and dried fruits. 
Mouthfeel is full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a big, sweet beer with a ton of flavor and character. Lots of dark fruit with caramel, toffee and tootsie rolls. Not something you would necessarily want to drink by yourself.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2015 Bourbon and booze smell.  Taste is chocolate, caramel, bourbon, and mild alcohol.  Thick body, light carbonation, no foam, and some alcohol heat

Bottleshare thanks to homer321. Aroma is lots of sugar and boost. Pours a ruby red color, minimal head. Taste is strong, really sweet, but still tasty. Lingers a but on my tongue. This is a certain sharer.

Bottle. Nose is boozy caramel sugar and vanilla. Poured deep red to brown. Small light brown head. Taste is very sweet and boozy. Could use something to balance the sweetness. Good but glad I could share this was others.

Bottle share thanks to Homer321. Big sweet, boozy, roasty, light dark fruity esters, marshmallow. Deep dark dark, mostly black, light tan head. Very sweet, lots of candy sugar light character, lots of sweet, smooth booze, some roast and residual sweetness. Lots of alcohol warmth.

Bottled 1 pt 9.4 fl oz, at rlgk + Aniela tasting, USA comes to Göteborg 2014, on October 18, 2014. Marked 16.8% ABV.Thanks to Marsiblursi!Clear dark brown color, small teal head. Sweet, alcohol, wood, oak, vanilla, resin, solvents scent. Very sweet, raisin, alcohol taste, also wood. Warming alcohol. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Sweet aftertaste, also oak.

Unclear deep amber color with a tan head. Vinous, bready and raisin aroma. Full body. A bit sweet and a moderate bitterness. Well the bitterness maybe drowns in the sweetness. Fruity, raisins, vanilla and oak in the flavor. Powerful ale. Also some alcohol coming up. Melange is butter in Norway. So I was a bit disappointed. Not much butter here. Well I do not like butter in beer anyway. Lovely balance at 15%![Bottle at rlgk plaza]

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2014 Bottle courtesy of marsiblursi. Pours dark brown with a small offwhite head that quickly dissipates while leaving some small spotty trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and boozy with toasted malts, caramel, toffee, maple syrup, charred wood, alcohol, figs, raisins, glue and hints of paint thinner. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter, malty and boozy with toasted malts, caramel, toffee, raisins in rum, prunes, figs, hay, charred wood, vanilla, brandy, madeira wine, alcohol and brown sugar. Mouthfeel is round, sticky sweet, boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is sweet, tiny bitter, malty and boozy with toasted malts, caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, charred wood, raisins in rum, figs, dates, prunes, hay, soil and alcohol. Way too sweet and boozy but has some redeeming complexity that would make me love to sip on this again in the future.

Bottle at USA comes to Göteborg 2014. Haxy deep amber/brown beer with a small head. Malty toffee aroma, figs and raisins, banana, vinous, caramel, some oak and spices. Sourish alcohol flavor, quite boozy, vanilla, vinous, figs and raisins, toffee. Too boozy and sweet.

Flaska på provningen USA comes to Göteborg 2014. 
Luktar surt, vin, russin, vanilj, kryddor, alkohol
Väldigt blaskig mörk färg.
Smakar, alkohol, surt, karamell, sirap, beskt, gräs, frukt.
Ganska fyllig.
Bottle @ rlgk. Pours cloudy darker amber with a small tanned head. Aroma is malty bready raisins boozy vinous vanilla. Flavor is as aroma bitter a bit acidy.

Bottle. Murky dark copper-brown color with very little head. Aroma is rich and awesome. Toffee, caramel, cherries, dates, licorice, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, and burnt brown sugar. Tastes great too. Big barrel influence without being too hot or boozy. All the aromas come through balanced well. Moderate to strong sweetness is toned down by the booze. Syrupy mouthfeel. Full body. Probably my favorite Bruery beer so far.

Brown pour with watery whitish head and lace. Aroma is brown sugar, roasted malt, dark fruit and oaky. Flavor is super sweet malt, brown sugar, dark fruity esters, nice abv warmth masked well by the sweet malt. A touch of BB with a flat lite finish. Medium bodied with good carbonation. a very nice beer

Draft at Ginger Man. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Rich malty sweetness, bourbon, chocolate, molasses and boozy sweetness, and caramel shews. Like a boozy chocolate candy. Ooof, I tend to like big overly sweet beers more than most, but this one is a bit too much.

"Possibly the most Ive ever paid retail, but worth it...one of my friend Daves favorite beers, period. That alone is worth it. I really really liked it. though its not quite in the upper stratosphere of the elite, it IS elite. Tempers a little of the sweetness of the slightly stronger Black Tuesday, and adds a little depth, though BT isnt exactly lacking there. Womderful, wonderful aroma (between a 9 & 10). Body is warming, still slightly cloying. Flavor (and aroma) a nice mix of vanilla, bourbon, roasted and sweet malts, sugary sweetness, tofee and deep fruits. One that I could sip all night for sure. I was juuust about ready to give it a 4.5, but I cant quite say I straight out like it BETTER than BT, so for now a 4.4. One more bottle thatll come out in the winter... "

Drought. Inky black with small foamy beige head, strong oak aroma, low carbonation, strong and sweet bourbon taste with sharp wood flavor, low carbonation, long finish with woody aftertaste. This is a great blend but the overpowering oak aroma is a bit too much.

750 ml bottle shared with the Quebec City crew. Pours a ruby reddish brown with a short lived whitish-beigeish head. Aroma is roast, coffee, prune, fig and caramel. Flavor is prune, fig, cherry, chocolate, loads of dirty caramel, port wine and some booze. Finish is chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, with lingering wood and booze. Medium to full body, soft, velvety mouthfeel, weak carbonation. A very solid brew.

Bottled @ Zeebra#2. 10cl sample. The aroma has bourbon, raisin, maple sirup, sweetness. Brown coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is sweet, has raisin, dark fruits, some chocolate, bourbon and a hint of pepper. Nice one.

Bottle shared with the epic. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, cookies, and vanilla oak. Pours typical Bruery muddy flat brown. Taste is tootsie roll chocolate, vanilla oak, bourbon, slight black cherry, and mince meat. Just delicious and not over the top sticky. Nice blend.

750 ml bottle. Pours a clear rich dark caramel brown with lasting poofy off white beige edge head. Aroma is vanilla, oak, sweet malt, light roast, and a pleasant bourbony smokiness. Flavor is a delicious smooth complex combination: same as above, with dark fruits. Alcohol well masked for a near 17%. One of my Bruery favorites.

Bottle (11 or 12; not sure). Murky dark brown pour with no head. Bourbon, dense raisin and toffee, light fruit and some alcohol spice. Taste is heavy bourbon with vanilla and thick, sweet raisins, dates, and trailing alcohol heat. Coating mouthfeel. Really nice sipper.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave and Ben on 5/23/2014.
Appearance:Pours a dark black brown.
Aroma: Aroma of chocolate, bourbon.
Taste: Boozy, chocolate, bourbon, oak.
Palate:Over medium body, alcohol is present.
Summary: Really glad I got to try this. The high abv makes it rough to have more than a split of, but that is okay. Really interesting mix.

Bottle share at my house. Snifters. Pours a very dark, opaque with a mild short-lived head. The aroma is powerful with caramel, malts, dough, booze, yeasts, hay, and oak. The taste is very complex with oak barrel, malts, caramel, chocolate, dark fruits, toffee, nuts, and leather. Full body, chewy finish of chocolate, caramel, oak, and booze. Mild carb, serious flavors.

Location: 750 ml bottle shared with dbarnold and jcos, 5/23/14


Aroma: The nose is rich, with some toffee, chocolate, bourbon, oak, and roasted malts

Appearance: Has a murky brown pour with a small off-white head and mild lace

Flavor: The taste is much the same, rich, malty, and boozy, a little sweet, mid-hot finish

Palate: The body is full, it has a rich feel, and you can certainly feel the big ABV

Overall Impression: 
I really enjoyed this one, but at the same time, Im pretty happy not to be drinking a full bottle myself.  You can tell very easily that this one is big on the ABV all the way through.

This was from the bottle sharing at Dark Lord Day 2014. It was sampled right after the Melange #3 and was even better.  Poured into my sample glass it was dark red tending toward black. Tan head. Nose of chocolate, dark ripe fruit, vanilla, wood, and hops.  Bold body. Creamy mouthfeel with alcohol.   Flavor is chocolate and the dark ripe fruit and all the other stuff is there...booze, vanilla and floral hops. Really rich and tasty but 2 oz was enough.

750ml, red waxed bottle. 2013 vintage. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate, and toasted nuts. Tastes of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits, wood, and caramel. Alcohol burn in the finish - but it is 16%.

Sampled at DLD 2014. It poured a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, oak and dark fruits. The taste was creamy and quite sweet with dark caramel, sweet bourbon, vanilla, toffee, dark fruits, some oak, light chocolate and had a boozy sweet finish. Tasty.
Bottled @ Zeebra #2, small sample. Slight hazy copper color, short head. Raisin, cookie, biscuit. Quite sweet, bit bitter. Lovely.

Bottle. The pour has a deep red hue to it. The aroma has a big bourbon to it. The taste is sweet and bourbon at the same time. Very smooth drinking big beer. Still a little hot. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ DLD. Brown sugar malt, sweet boozy bourbon, oak, vanilla, and cherry aroma. Bloudy brown with a small tan head. Brown sugar, dark fruity , big boozy bourbon, vanilla, and earthy oak flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation. Nice.
Shared during DLD bottle share. It definitely tastes like what you would expect. It has a ton of dark fruit character to it and not a lot of roasty stout qualities.Sweet and syrupy.
Tasting at dld. Poured brown light head. Aroma of dark sweet fruit. Taste similar.
Had this at a great neighborhood tasting. Thanks to everyone for sharing! Had so much fun!
wow, this was much better than i thought it was going to be, like a stout mixed with a rich red wine. very nice.

March 22, 2014 - on tap at Bruery tasting room. Brown pour with limited head. Wood, dark fruit and toffee in the aroma. Taste was consistent with aroma, but here is where the bourbon comes out. Very smooth with a touch of heat in the finish.

Hazy medium brown color with red highlights and a one-finger tan head that dissipated quickly and left no lace. Heavy bourbon aroma to go along with dominating brown sugar and molasses. Oak, maple and vanilla notes. Sweetness of the brown sugar and molasses is almost overpowering, and accentuated by an alcohol burn. Hints of dark fruit and chocolate. Full body, no carbonation, thick syrupy mouthfeel and a lingering sweetness. Very boozy. I understand what theyre trying to do here, and I acknowledge it as a well-crafted beer, but this is too over-the-top for me.
One of the few beers I had at the Hellshire IV release that completely blew me away. great aromas of bourbon, booze, carmel, vanilla, on and on. great stuff

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2015 This is the holy grail of bourbon barrel aged stuff so far for me, proudly alongside Goose Island;s BCS. Pours pitch black with a clear white head. Aroma is huge bourbon, chocolate, burnt caramel, dark malts. Mouthfeel is full bodied, slightly sticky, decent carbonation without being too aggressive, warmth from the booze. Taste is huge bourbon, oak, slight smokiness, vanilla, chocolate, butterscotch, enormous sweetness which overtakes the bitterness, and a background slight tartness from the white sap. Insanely complex, insanely delicious. Sweetness might be a bit much for some, 

This is a real marvel of a beer; totally delicious.

Bottle pours slightly cloudy dark brown with small tan head. Aroma malts, booze, vanilla. Great taste of chocolate caramel, vanilla, bourbon, dark cherries, dark fruits, slight oak. Finish mainly a continuation of the taste. palate maybe just a bit thin but doesnt detract. Alcohol apparent. Very nice.

Hazy brownish in color... Aroma of caramel, oak, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate... Flavor is sweet initially, notes of wheat wine, white chocolate, tobacco, oak, bourbon... Body is thinner than the BT... Really enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle, pours a deep ruby read, almost no head or lacing. big bold nose, tons of alcohol, oak, sweet sugars. very sweet yet deep taste, oak, ripe plum, alcohol. clean dry finish. great beer.

pours hazy dark brown reddish with a small light beige head, some retention, nice lacing and nice legs sticking. cherries and raisins-galore, tobacco, dark and smooth milk chocolate, spices, vanilla, burnt caramel, nicely woodsy, coconut. moderate to low carbonation, medium to full body - oily, sticky and i guess cloying, but im digging these sugars. warming, very tasty and good.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by mathieuc, thanks! Brown with reddish reflects and a light ring of beige foam. Aroma is boozy with caramel, vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate, fruity notes and sweetness. Taste is moderately sweet and quite boozy with chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, caramel and a warming/burning finish. Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Sirupy mouthfeel. Complex, but too boozy and not well balanced. Decent sipper.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours brown with low beige head. Red reflects, minimal lacing. Aroma is of alcohol, fruits, caramel. Taste is of chocolate, caramel, sweetness, roasted malt, heavy alcohol, nuts, spices. Palate: Full bodied. Very sweet. Questionnable balance (lots of sugar). Cloying. Low carbonation. Overall: Pretty good, but too heavy on sugar.

Pours a dark brown with no head but thats OK for such a big brew, I guess. Aroma is of raw alcohol, caramel and a little chocolate. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate and maple syrup. Pretty sweet but somewhat balanced. Body is full, mouthfeel slightly syrupy. Finish is hot and full of maple syrup/brown sugar. A good sipper but I think I expected more, the nose wasnt particularly pleasing and all the booze distracting really...

750ml bottle in a teku. Pours deep, murky brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of chocolate and toffee malts, some oak and vanilla, light bourbon, and hints of alcohol. Flavor the same with a nice maltiness that blends well with the oak and bourbon. Smooth, thicker texture. A pretty good beer but sort of simple.

On tap at The Bruery, poured into mini-snifter (which would prove to be plenty). Appearance is dark reddish-brown with a tan head, streaks, and minimal lacing, which is not unexpected for such a high abv beer. Aroma is powerful butterscotch, vanilla, toffee, cocoa, bourbon heat, roasted malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, and oak. Taste is very sweet with toffee, vanilla, and fig up front. Some oaky bitterness, but not balanced whatsoever. And heat, but less than the 15% on the bottle prepared me for. A sipper, certainly, due to both booze and sweetness. Full bodied, thick, slightly oily texture, low carbonation, sweet, warming finish.
Poured a clear medium brown with a small off white head. Aroma of alcohol soaked fruit and caramel malt. Full body, flavour as per the aroma, some liquorice over an oily mouthfeel.

Bottle @ Deans Winter Shelter Tasting, courtesy of allesmetkaas. Pours a clear light brown beer with a small ring of off white head. Aroma has barrel characteristics, malts, chocolate and vanilla. Very nice. The flavor is sweet, oaky and alchoholic. Very sweet flavor overall, perhaps a bit too sweet for me. Still a very nice, impressive full bodied beer of epic proportions. Very nice!

Dark brown with a tan, lacy, slides off the glass, thin head. Smells of sweet malt, caramel, brown sugar, raisins, plums, figs and roast. Medium oily body. Tastes of smoke malt, roast, chocolate, coffee and so much malt, with liquorish, and caramel. Decent and full of sweetness.

Bottle at Deans Winter Shelter Tasting. Poured a clear dark brown with a round bubbly white head. The aroma is boozy alcohol and liqourice. The flavour is moderate sweet light bitter with a big fruit woody alcoholic palate. Full bodied with flat carbonation and an oily mouthfeel.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Sample courtesy of and shared with Allesmetkaas.
thin off white head. Clear deep burgundy pour. Nice complex brew. Lovely beer
Zu süßer Antrunk mit Vanillenoten. Gerade die Vanillenoten retten auch den Mittelteil, der sonst viel zu süß ist. Rumnoten, fruchtig, OK. 10/11/8/12/12/11

Bottle at Exira Beer Summit IV. Thanks to adnielsen for bringing. Pours a deep brown color with white head. Caramel, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla aromas. A lot of vanilla, sweet/sugary, bourbon, chocolate in the flavors.

2012 vintage. Pours a very dark ruby brown. Short fizzy head. Just phenomenal. Deep, complex, rich, luscious. Despite the abv the alcohol presence is subtle, smooth bourbon. Dark fruit, raisin, port, caramel, chocolate... so much going on and so balanced and smooth its hard to pick things out while all Im thinking is wow this is good. Full body, Silky smooth, viscous, honey sweet. Pleasant alcohol warmth. Among the best beers Ive had.

Deep brown with a small tan head. Aroma is interesting - port wine, oak, vanilla, molasses. Flavor is a bit underwhelming because the alcohol overpowers everything else. Some notes of figs, chocolate, and oak. Too boozy for me.

Poured a dark amber color with aromas all ver the place, vanilla, oak, chocolate, roast, toffee, Caramel and some nuts. Flavors are the same a great mixture of that with some booze, a solid beer overall.

Traded bottle. I was honestly afraid about the large ABV for this beer but it turned out to be not too bad. This really is a big beer, just like you mixed a barley wine with an imperial stout. There is a little booze burn through in the aroma and flavor. It does have a nice mix of sweet and rich malt. Pretty good.

This ale is medium dark brown in color, with a really nice nose of a bourbon barrel aged barleywine. Its really a gorgeous beer. Im so surprised. Its full, flavorful, and quite exceptional. The soft, smooth, and beautiful beer is thick, with bourbon. Theres just the right amount of everything in all aspects of the beer. Its complex, and very well-blended. Im in love with this beer.

Pours dark cola with a huge pillowy three finger off white head.

Smell big coffee and caramel, complex, raisin, red fruit, toffee. Very nice.

Taste boozy raisin, bourbon vanilla, slightly tart cranberry, red fruit, oak. Getting a lot more of the White Oak and Anniversary beer out of the flavor. 

Very sweet, but not cloying. Fuller bodied. 

Pretty damn good if you like big sweet beers.

Had it from the bottle. Looks really nice. Does not carbonate that much, but looks nice and dark, with a small head. Smells truly rich and awesome. However, the taste is not exceptional. Sweet and chocolate but a very heavy overwhelming alcohol taste. Still a very nice beer.

A: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes No Light, Creamy White Head, Some Lacing

S: Bourbon, Tobacco, Raisins

T: Fig, Raisins, Bourbon (Well Balanced)

M: Decent Carbonation, Full Bodied, Smooth Sweetness

Overall, a solid well balanced strong ale with a definite barrel aged presence but doesnt overpower you. Outstanding.

Huge thanks to Ryan for bringing a bottle of this in for the staff at CK! Beautiful cloudy garnet pour, minimal head. Nose and flavor bring just what youd expect, but man is it well done: beautiful notes of boozy vanilla sweetness, toffee, molasses, caramel, port wine and madeira, hints of oaky bite. Sweet but not at all cloying, obscenely rich, divine. Decadent and delicious.

Aroma is great rich vanilla, caramel, bourbon, and plums. Taste is very sweet and cant be consumed in quantity at all. I can take very small boozy sips and enjoy them but it hits you with palate fatigue quick.
A lot going on with this beer, but damn its good. Slight sour, with slight wine barrel taste and lots of malt.

On tap at the Bruery. Im not sure what went on here with this brew, maybe because I had after Bois. There was hardly any aroma. I tasted a slight hint of bourbon with overtones of vanilla and cinnamon. I could tell it was 15.5% Ill chalk this letdown up to a bad pour/or all the other brews before were just better.
Bottle share by Bryce, Cinnamon, nutty and dark pitted fruit aroma. Taste is dark fruit, chocolate and booze, needs some age.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 19.06.2013, tap @ The Ginger Man NY:
Small shortlasting head. Aroma is slightly rich and sweet, dark malts, dried dark fruits, dark sugar, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, grass, chocolate. Taste is slightly concentrated sweet fruity, caramel malts, dried dark fruits, grass, toffee, citrus, dark sugar, alcohol, oak, hops, bourbon, vanilla, citrus peel, almond. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Nice one, well hidden alcohol for being this strong.
Bottle. Clear dark maroon color, tan edge head. Aroma has tons of dark fruit, nuts. Taste has coffee, plums, dates, toffee. Sweet stuff, but very tasty.
Draft. Black pour with tan head. Chocolate, oak, vanilla and other sweet flavors. I enjoy the blend better than the parts.
Wow what a strong blend, a little to sweet and strong for me, really boozy and on the nose, oh well its not that bad

Bottle -- thanks, Matt! The beer that pushed me over the edge of sobriety at last nights tasting. Anyway: Pours mahogany with no head. Dark fruit, booze, caramel, sexy, yum. Syrupy, sweet. Im pretty sure that this description is basically a variation of what I wrote for Bois.
Pours a very cloudy brown-amber. Nearly no head. Tart grape and sweet bourbon barrel aromas. Tastes like port wine aged in bourbon barrels. A lot of chocolate flavors too. This is a winner.

Blind tasting thanks to Adam! Dark looking brown color with thin white head. Nose is very stout like. Oak, roasted malt, toasted caramel and vanilla. Flavor has plenty of vanilla with chocolate malts upfront. The bourbon is really obvious in the finish with some chocolate and raisins. Molasses and sugar notes. I dont know how old the bottle was but the 15.5 % ABV wasnt really harsh at all. It did let me know it was there 10 minutes after I finished the snifter but the alcohol wasnt real apparent in the flavor. BIG malty sweet bomb. Really, really good stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Tap at the brewpub. Beautiful beer. Very dark pour with a small tan head. Oak, bourbon, and vanilla jump out on the aroma. Palate isnt overly heavy for a beer this big. Taste is rich and sweet, but far from cloying. Awesome.

What an awesome beer the Bruery has created here! Pours a deep brown with a nice head despite the alcohol content. (It doesnt last though). Aroma is chocolate, plums, and toffee. The flavor is where this beer simply shines more than any Ive had. Sweet and bitter, the alcohol balances the deep purple fruit and and creamy chocolate flavors. Finish is sweet and cleans up nicely leaving a longing for more. Fantastic!

750 ml bottle. Pours a darker copper with a beige head of foam. The aroma has big woody notes and lots of booze. The taste is sweet and boozy. Really thick mouthfeel, but for as beastly as this beer is, I dont expect anything else.

Appearance clear me black with tiny creamy diminishing off white head, no lacing. Aromas are oak, bourbon, sweet rich malts, vanilla, deep fruits, buzzing alcohol. Taste are sweet malt backbone, raisin, fig, date, cherry, vanilla, smooth bourbon oakyness with warmth of alcohol. Palate is soft oily smooth CO2 with full creamy slick body, then lasting complex fruity warming finish. Bottle share with deadCATAtlanta. Probably should have a grabbed a few more beer nerds to share this with as this beer was big and boozy. Scent is maple syrup, vanilla, and booze. Super sweet with the bourbon flavors coming through. Medium heavy body with light carbonation. Fun beer that needs to be split 4-5 ways. Bottle - Share with deadCATAtlanta

Draught @ The Bruery, Placentia, CA
Pours clear dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, bourbon, oak, vanilla and alcohol. Taste is heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, vanilla, oak and toffee finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat.

On tap at the taproom. A clear looking dark brown beer with a minimal sized light beige head. The aroma has caramel, dried fruits, some alcohol and lots of raisins. Pleasantly mellow and well merged. The flavor is sweet, with alcohol warmth, its full bodied and very softly carbonated. Lots of flavors, roasted malt hints, raisins, generic dried fruits, licorice notes, coffee and dark chocolate. Really long finish. Wow, this is gorgeous. 130811

On tap at The Bruery. Pours dark amber with a tiny of white head. Aroma of caramel, alcohol, toffee, malt, raisins and bread crust. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some dark red berries, oak, warming alcohol, grapes and vanilla. Full body, soft carbonation.

Pours dark brown with a thick brownish head that recedes to a few clouds. Aroma is booze, brown sugar, and major barrel. The taste is really boozy, with heavy caramel, brown sugar, sherry, bourbon, raisin, toffee..... I could keep going. Theres alot going on but its also super boozy.

Huge thanks to Mike M!!! Wow this thing is a ton!! Pours a deeP dark and murky amber brown. Nose is as boozy and smooth! Chocolate notes and plenty of caramel, pretty decent sweetness. Pours hazy brown with about a finger of frothy tan head. Aroma of port barrel, muscovado, chocolate, dates, raisins, figs, light molasses. Complex, sweet and absolutely marvelous aroma! 750ml bottle, thanks to caterwaul for sharing. Mostly hazy dark brown / red color. Good thin khaki head. Nice, plentiful dots of lace. Bigger body. Smooth, creamy, lighter carbonation. Drinks amazingly for 15%. A light amount of warmth, that is actually pretty nice. A good amount of warmth... no bite or burn at all, very very smooth. Fantastic stuff, impressively balanced, very delicious. Rapidly sippable, every sip is wonderful.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, oak and dark fruit. Flavor was creamy smooth and quite sweet with dark caramel, sweet bourbon, vanilla, toffee, dark fruit, oak, light chocolate and had a boozy sweet finish.

Very dark brown, thin off-white lacing. Strong aroma of booze, charred oak, caramel, raisins, overripe figs, vanilla, and a little chocolate. Light sour taste from the barrel mingled with spicy notes. Smooth, but heavy, sticky, and full-bodied. Boozy and warming finish.

This is really good..
Pours dark amber with purple tinge. Aroma is primarily vanilla, oak and bourbon with a hint of dark fruits. Very smooth, complex with light smoke. Finishes tart and sticky.
Bottle share. Cloudy blood red. Crazy bourbon wood jizzery. I wish I had more. All of it.

Bottle generously shared by John after Hill Farm anniversary. Smooth, bourbon, cherries, toffee, cocoa and some barrel, a little hot overall but lots going on here. Thick mouth. If it was smoother it would be a home run.

Dark brown with a minimal head. Aroma is raisins, plums, dates, brown sugar, maple syrup. Lightly carbonated, syrupy mouthfeel, sweet and fruity on the palate with a hint of booze on the finish. Taste is raisins, plums, chocolate, toffee, sherry and a subtle hint of wood. Damn tasty.

Complex aroma and taste with a strong taste, aggressive mouthfeel and dark brown appearance.

Taste is a mix between bourbon and vanilla notes with some oak, dark fruit and some vinous notes which feels more or less balanced with the rest of the mix. Body is full with limited filtration and light warming alcohol. I didnt really dig the mix between rich stout/old ale sweet notes and the dark fruit and also vinous feels of the beer.

ZEBF13
smell is very bourbon. way to much, actualy. 
very low carbo. buttery, bitter. thick. low carbo. OK, bourbon aftertaste.

Bottle thanks to Kevin. Pours a very dark brown with light tan head that lasts awhile. The aroma is oak, dark fruits, and chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with sweet chocolate and roast with nice oak finish. Hides alcohol well, a very impressive American strong ale from The Bruery.
22 ounce shared bottle.  Pours dark brown with a tiny tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, caramel, and vanilla.  Taste is bourbon, chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, and vanilla.  Sweet and warming.

Tap. Pours deep clear mahogany, small tan head, some lacing. Fantastic aroma of dried fruit, mosses, toffee, whiskey, wood, vanilla. Flavor is the same, but less of it, medium sweet, very hot. Medium body, creamy.

thanks to Owen

pours a dark brown, no head at all. A few gurgles of carbonation. Quite thick looking and sticks to the glass well. Obvious ABV legs.

decadent smell. Bourbon, caramel, brown sugar, coconut and oak. Slightly sweet nose but offset well by the ingredients. Lots of alcohol in the nose.

Head: almost nothing + pretty flat beer itself 
Colour: dark brown 
Smell: lots of bourbon and vanilla with notes of caramel 
Taste: sweet in the start, toffee and caramel with lots of bourbon and the typical vanilla taste, also lots of booze ! not bad but a bit overwhelming ( altough i allready had allot of beers before this one ! )
750 ml bottle - thanks to BelgBeerGeek - pours deep amber with no head. Aroma of malt and thick bread... plums, raisins, and so on. Most balanced bourbon bruery beer so far.

Huge, boozy, mish-mash of flavors, fruits, cocoa, not the darkest beer. But somehow it works.
Bottle at a bottle share. Pours a very dark brown color. Nose has a huge amount of bourbon coming off it. Smells and tastes very much like a barley wine, with a smooth finish. Interesting.

Big Thanks to Dave for sharing this ! Pour a deep brownish umber with traces of copper on the edges, big foamy eggshell head. 750ml bottle.
Been wanting to try this one for some time.  Deep amber brown pour with a bit of tan head.  Nose is ridiculous - caramel, tons of vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit, chocolate, so complex!  Slight sweetness, vanilla, lots of barrel flavor, brown sugar, toffee.  Amazing.

On draught at Lucky Labrador Barleywine and Big Beer Festival. Toffee and chocolate aroma. Chocolate, prune, caramel, liquor flavors. Though the alcohol packs a punch, it finishes really well, with a sugarplum aftertaste.

Flöska. Deep brown colour, red hue, beige medium head. Pleasant sweet  dark fruity malty bourbon caramel aroma, little chocolate too. Good mouthfeel. Sweet malty caramel bourbon dark fruity vanilla alco flavour. Quite pleasant.

Bottled. Pours dark ruby with a creamy beige head. The aroma is sweet bourbon, oak, wood, caramel and toffee. Lots of things going on. The flavor is sweet bourbon, chocolate, wood, vanilla and oak. Long sweet malty finish. To the sweet side but great!

Bottle @ Cecil spring tasting ´13... It pours clear dark brown with a small bubbly light tan head... The aroma is bourbon, sweet dark fruits, vanilla and wood... The flavor is sweet dark fruits, bourbon, wood like oak warming alcohol and caramel.....

As always, The Bruery does an excellent job. This is but one of their fine gems! Although a bit strong, it packs a punch to your mouth!

Bottle.  Multiple vintages.  This one is a monster.  Pitch black pour with very little head and no lacing.  Nose is similar to Black Tuesday with huge sweet malt, vanilla, oak and bourbon.  Taste follows the nose with a ton of vanilla and chocolate sweetness, bourbon, wood, and roast.  White Oak Sap is a great beer to blend into this as it gives the mouthfeel at least a little lift but still maintains the sweetness.  This was bound to be a huge winner for me given the blend of what I feel are the Bruerys two best beers.  Black Tuesday and their Anniversery series old ales.  Out of this world stuff.

A huge beer. Thick. Rich. Bold. Concentrated. Full bodied. Dark. Vanilla. A little sweet. On the edge of being a dessert beer. Solid. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

The perfect ending to an incredibly crappy day. 
Pours a deep burnished brown with faint ruby at the edges and a smallish tightly bubbled khaki head that slowly dissipates to a ring on top. The smell of bourbon and oak hit my nostrils as soon as I pop the cap off the top. Upon closer inspection I am greeted with light and brown sugars with a fair amount of dark pitted fruit and a hint of ethanol. the flavor is sweet up front with brown and syrupy sugar. Dark and light fruit come next along with a bit of vanilla and wood. The alcohol and bourbon come in next with a ferocity that wont quit. Long lingering tannic wood and alcohol burn long after the sweet liquid settles to the bottom floor. Medium to thick body with a light to moderate level of carbonation and a sweet harsh alcoholic mouthfeel. Nice sipper, but there is no denying the alcohol content of this one. This is tasty but it needs some time to settle down.

Had to open this beer because now that Im an RS member, Im going to order some beers and need to know whats worth ordering. Broke this out of the cellar despite not drinking in January. The wax was a pain in the ass to remove as if Bruery didnt want me to try this delicious amazing beer.

Poured a minimal head that faded fast. Amber to brown hues, very clear. 

Nose is very much big vanilla and wheat wine sweetness. Lots of caramel / toffee on the nose.

Taste..wow. VERY sweet, very apparent bourbon booziness but not in a hot boozy alcohol well. just the taste with none of the boozy characters like burn that youd get from a 15%+ beer. Loads of caramel, oak and heavy bittersweet chocolate. Some figs and finish is vanilla bourbon.

Thin mouthfeel, very very delicious. Wow. Going to order a few of these to enjoy some more of this delicious remarkable beer.

2012 bottle; recollection of 2010 and 2011 bottles is similar.  Poured into a tulip.  Dark brown/red color with almost no head.  Nose is bourbon, sugar, molasses.  Taste is bourbon/booze, dates, dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla.  Great mouthfeel.  Interesting, complex and delicious.

Bottle. Almost clear, deep ruby liquid with small to medium off-white head. Aroma of wood, light chocolate, toffee, booze, raw sugar, dark fruit and salt licorice. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar, toffee and booze. Medium to full bodied with low to medium carbonation. Very nice, balanced but a bit boozy.

P: a very dark brown with a head that dispenses towards the edge of the glass. S: Alcohol, mollasses, bourbon, toffee, old wood, and hints of vanilla. Draft at Bruery Provisions.  Pours black with thick tan head. Nose of chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak.  Taste of chocolate, maple syrup, vanilla, oak.  Syrupy mouthfeel with a boozy finish.

2011 bottle. Clear ruby-dark brown color with almost no head. Beautiful aroma of bourbon and burnt sugar sweetness. An incredible blend of dates, boozy bourbon, biscuit, and maltiness, with touches of dark chocolate. I can detect the imperial stout, wheat wine and old ale in the mix. Perfect medium soft palate. Still one of my favorite Bruery beers.

A beer I have been wanting to try for years. I cracked this open with a good buddy during the football games this weekend. 

The beer appears walnut brown with subtle burgundy highlights. Small off white head that leaves minimal lacing on the goblet.

Smell is phenomenal. Oak, vanilla, bourbon, malt, sugar cookies...wow...yes, please. 

Flavor = silky smooth. Staggering! What just happened?!? I am instantly convinced that I need to fill a portion of my cellar with this delectable concoction. Go Patrick! A vanilla and toffee bomb. Black Tuesday emerges more than the White Oak and Papier. Wonderfully complex and insanely delicious. Beautiful milk and dark chocolates. Likely the best strong ale I have ever had. 

Feel = give me more ASAP. Delicate and smooth. Hard to believe this is 15% abv. Lingering flavors of vanilla, bourbon and toffee.

Shocking. World class. So grateful to try it. My highest recommendation.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-23-2012

Bottle at Home, served in a snifter. Pour is deep crimson in appearance with a small off-white head and decent lacing. Taste is rich toffee, dark fruits, red licorice, a touch of bourbon, figs, sweet vanilla, dough, and roast with an alcoholic burn on the finish. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Begins sweet and rich upfront, leading to a woody and fruity middle, ending with a smooth alcoholic burn that really adds to the complexity of this beer. Nice stuff!

Bottle; Pour is dark, murky, amber brown with a modest fine bubbled off white head in this glass. It retains fairly well here, ringing the glass. The nose is sherry, cocoa, cherry, biscuits, vanilla, and toffee. More cherry, chocolate, bready malts, vanilla, earthy oak initial ; this one is smoother than expected, and not as boozy as expected either. "Tastes like soy sauce", the girlfriend says. This is a nice one that grows with some sitting time, for sure.
Bottle shared by a friend. Cloudy brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of booze, caramel and a bit of chocolate. Caramel and bourbon flavor with a bit of fruit before a boozy finish.

Rate 800-Pours a mahogany with a ruby head. The nose and taste is sweet, hints of bourbon and oak. This beer was very approachable and balanced for 15.5%. Lots of vanilla, toffee, a bit of leather, plum and raisin. This beer is brilliantly balanced and IMO far better than Black Tuesday.

bottle. pour is dark brown with minimal head which is only thing that brought rating down. aroma is like a BA stout lots of barrel and roast malt. taste  is the same chocolate and brown sugar

2011, Batch 2, 15% ABV, 750ml into a tulip glass. Huge thanks to Rempo!

A - Pours a murky dark brown body with a red tinge when held up to the light. Initial pour yields a nice one finger light tan head with large bubbles. Settles down quickly to a thick edging. Decent amount of lacing for this amount of abv. Sticky alcoholic legs that last forever.

S - Big in every way. Molasses, dark caramelized fruit, bitter chocolate, leather, and huge bourbon notes of vanilla and oak. Sweet and spicy with some robust and savory notes. This beer is just all over the place, a complete diabetic complexity. Its smells so damn tasty though. Ive had Cuir, and its very reminiscent of that but with more depth and a touch of stout notes. It does smell primarily like an old ale though.

T - The taste is also massive. Super syrupy malt sweetness. Caramelized dark fruit, molasses, toffee, maple, and smokey leather. Like the nose, this leans toward the anniversary beer more so than the Black Tuesday and White Oak. Bourbon barrel notes of oak and vanilla on the finish along with a huge yet pleasant alcohol burn. I get the slightest hint of chocolate and coffee on the end as well, but its all about the fruit here.

M - Thick, coating, chewy and syrupy. Medium level of carbonation. Huge booze warmth, but the thickness is really what holds back the drinkability. 15% is very well integrated though.

O - A huge beer of massive complexity. Ive only had Cuir on its own and I do detect a lot of those flavors. I was hoping for some more action from the Back Tuesday or the White Oak Sap. Its still an amazing beer and accomplishment though. The Bruery can work wonders with insanely high gravity thick brews. It lived up to my expectations for sure.
Shared at Woodshop 7. A bit less than the sum of its parts. Pretty strong and sweet with caramel and chocolate, hot barrel, nuts, and vanilla.

Real good beer, would like to retry without the bottom dregs.
@ Daks party. Nearly black pour. A lot going on in this beer- cocoa, chocolate, some wood & vanilla. Even some soy sauce in there, too. Dark, pit fruits. Incredible! Hard to put into words.

S: Immediate boozines stings the nostrils, chocolate, caramel, raisin, oak and vanilla.

T: Delicous and amazing! Booze soaked fruits and chocolate covered raisins, chocolate, bourbon, oak and vanilla just like the nose. I also get a nice Eartiness that goes beyond the oak.

M: Big body, loads of flavor

O: Just delicous and I see it being cellar worthy for sure

Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to Callmecoon for this. 2011 vintage I presume.

4.0 A: Black color in the glass, but it didnt look so dark during the pour. Oh well. Two fingers of beige frothy head. Retention is very good given the ABV, but nothing is left with regard to lacing.

4.5 S: Intensely sweet with huge dollops of caramel, toffee, and molasses. Lots of oak and vanilla in this. Leathery bourbon booziness. Fair amount of chocolate and dark fruits with emphasis on prune and fig. The aromas from the base beers blend quite well together. 

3.5 T: Again, intensely sweet. The decision to drink this alone was a bad one, but I will persist. Anyway, this reminds me a lot of straight up Black Tuesday in that the sweetness goes unchecked and the booze is almost as bad. However, both the sweetness and booze are a little lower in magnitude. Anyway, a lot of caramel, toffee, molasses again. Chocolate, fig, plum, prune, melon, vanilla, and oak. Leathery bourbon, brown sugar, butterscotch. Huge all around.

4.0 M: Syruppy heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Velvety creaminess. The only problem is the amylase coagulation that is going on.

4.0 D: An intense beer. I got through the whole bottle and it wasnt so bad. Yes, the sweetness is trying, but the flavor profile is pretty good.

2011 Release, Sampled March 2012
A soft pour into my small tulip glass produces a fat-two-finger thick, pale brown tinged, dirty tan colored head.  The ber is a concentrated brown / amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, cranberry-ruby hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells quite alcoholic, but has lots of other notes as well, but that is certainly prominent.  Notes of vanillin, toasted coconut, Sherry, lots of nut like notes, toasted caramel, sweet caramelized brown bread. The sherry character is actually quite striking, both the alcohol, the rich, sweet nutty notes and the oxidized malt contribute to this really smelling quite a bit like sherry. This definitely smells like desert in a glass.

As expected, from the nose, this beer is quite sweet; the sweetness seems a touch simplistic / sugary as opposed to really rich, concentrated malt like in character, by which I mean there seems to be a fair amount of residual, simple sugars left in this beer. The body is certainly viscous, but actually somehow seems light for a beer of this strength; much of the, perceived, lightness is likely contributed by the amply noticeable, warming and even hot, alcohol notes that play a prominent role in the flavor. Ample flavors of sweet coconut, vanillin, sugar coated / toasted nuts, sweet sherry, amaretto, and perhaps a touch of brandy like fruit character are noticeable. Woody oak, with a touch of astringency and some spiciness comes into and lingers through the finish; the alcohol also lends to the spiciness and heat in the finish. There is a definite fruitiness here as well, it is sort of evocative of prune juice, perhaps a touch of fig and raisin as well. Other flavors of maple syrup, toasted oak, brown sugar syrup, touches of roasted bitterness in the finish, and a toasted, brown bread note add some character. 

This is definitely a HOT beer, at this alcohol level that is not unexpected, but I cant say that I necessarily appreciate that either. The sweetness is also a bit too simplistic in this beer; I would have been more appreciative if the malt character was less simple sugar focused and had more of a dense, almost savory, concentrated malt character. Interestingly enough, given how hot this beer is, I dont get as much Bourbon character as I was expecting; more of the vanillin, spicy oak, and toasted oak come out individually rather than reminiscent of actual Bourbon. Not a bad beer if you are only having a couple ounces as a nightcap, but anything more for me is just a bit underwhelming (not complex enough in flavor) and overwhelming (in the hot alcohol and sugary sweetness) at the same time. I must say that I really like the oxidized malt character / sherry notes that are on display here (is this the anniversary old ale contribution), it really adds an extra dimension that keeps me much more interested than I otherwise would be. Drinkable and even enjoyable in small amounts if I am not critically evaluating the beer. Before cracking this beer, I had not reallized how strong it was going to be, I wish I had, as I would have planned to use the rest of the beer for cooking of some sort; I could imagine this being used quite well in a rum cake recipe, or even a dense fruit cake would likely be a perfect use (just make sure to reduce the level of sugar called out for in the recipe to account).  I am planning on this already with the bottle of Black Tuesday that I am opening; in fact I am almost more excited about the Imperial chocolate stout cake that I am going to make than actually drinking the beer :-).

T: Complex. It combined wonderful sweet notes of chocolate, vanilla, caramel and molasses with the earthy nature of oak, bourbon, and leathery malts. Nice dark fruit component of figs and raisins. Maybe a little roasted coffee towards the finish.

M: Thick, but sufficiently carbonated to keep the beer fairly smooth on the palate. Nice warming heat from the booze, but its mostly on the tongue as opposed to burning in the back of the throat. Nice lingering sweet malty finish.

O: I thoroughly enjoyed this. So much so that I easily put two glasses back in about an hour and a half. I was a big fan of both white oak and black tuesday so I am definitely not surprised to love this offering from Patrick and the gang.

Hands down one of the best beers I have ever had.
